Thanks, Jim, for the quick pointers re: Owari iron.  All good to 
know and =
remember.  I would imagine, too, that the particular period 
one is conside=
ring would play a role, too, no?  I guess I would 
expect that even Owari i=
ron would be less "worked," less "dramatic" 
with the coming of the Edo per=
iod...  

On the weight of the Nobuiye, yes, if the plate is considerably 
=
thinner than the rim, I could see where the tsuba wouldn't be quite 
as hea=
vy as it appears at first glance.  Interesting thoughts, too, 
on Nobuiye b=
eing the first to develop heavier guards.  Is it correct 
to suppose that t=
he shift to the "two-hand swords" at the time of 
Nobuiye might have been i=
nfluential...?  Thanks again, Jim.

Steven


--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroup=
s.com, "Jim Gilbert" <jggilbert@...> 
wrote:
>
> Steven,
> Even though the =
rim is thick, the plate itself is fairly thin, so 
it's not as heavy as you=
 might think.   Compared to earlier sukashi 
and ita tsuba though, it is he=
avy.  Nobuie was probably the first to 
make heavier guards, but I'd have t=
o think about that a bit more.
> 
> Regarding Owari iron, go back through t=
he previous kantei two 
albums and as a group consider the metal, hammer wo=
rk, tekkotsu 
and "melted" finish.  These are all typical of early Owari ar=
ea 
work.  Also this album about tekkotsu
> http://ph.groups.yahoo.com/grou=
p/nihontostudy/photos/browse/d4b0 
are all Owari region.
> 
> By comparison=
 Kyoto iron has a softer look to it, more homogenous, 
shows less modulatio=
n in the hammering, generally does not show 
prominent tekkotsu or a melted=
 finish (although some Ko-Shoami will 
have this).  Some would say more ref=
ined, others would say more 
boring.  Think Kyo-sukashi, Heianjo, Onin, Kan=
eie, etc.  Usually it 
is more of a brown color rather than blue-black of O=
wari (all 
caveats about color in effect).
> 
> It's probably not possible =
to explain without examples in hand, 
but try to look carefully at the phot=
os.  Even with examples in hand 
it takes some years of effort to see.
> 
>=
 Jim

 gives it 
away when one identifies a 
>   particular tsuba's iron as "clea=
rly Owari"...?  Thanks again, 
Jim, for another great Kantei.  
>   Already=
 looking forward to another...
